title: Mainstreaming Management, Operations, and Intelligent Transportation Systems into the Planning Process
description: This paper discusses the integration of Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) and Management and Operations (M&O) into institutionalized transportation planning and programming processes. It consolidates experience from Transportation System Management (TSM), congestion management systems (CMS), and ITS deployment planning. The research emphasizes the importance of ITS as a principal means to enhance mobility, safety, and service reliability under real-time conditions. Highlighting driving forces like increasing demand, limited new capacity, and technological advances, the paper proposes an operational framework centered on efficiency and user-oriented performance. Key challenges include institutional collaboration, policy reorientation, technical system integration, and resource allocation. The work serves as a guide to policymakers for advancing regional integration of ITS and promoting innovative, responsive transportation solutions for 21st-century challenges.

Incorporate real-time service monitoring and feedback into planning.
Use systems engineering to align user-service requirements with ITS functionalities.
Address incident management to reduce travel delays and improve reliability.
Integrate freeway and arterial traffic operations for enhanced efficiency.
Promote public-private partnerships for ITS service provision.
Utilize ITS-generated data for dynamic traffic modeling and operational insights.

advantages: Improves efficiency of existing transportation infrastructure.

Facilitates regional and intermodal coordination.

drawbacks: High initial cost of ITS infrastructure and deployment.
Dependence on accurate and interoperable data systems.
Institutional resistance to shifting from traditional planning methods.
Challenges in achieving multi-jurisdictional cooperation.
Ongoing operational costs for monitoring and maintenance.

title: Effects of Catastrophic Events on Transportation System Management and Operations: Howard Street Tunnel Fire, Baltimore City, Maryland – July 18, 2001
description: This report examines the response to the catastrophic Howard Street Tunnel fire in Baltimore City, Maryland, which occurred on July 18, 2001. The incident involved the derailment of a 60-car freight train carrying hazardous materials, leading to a significant fire and a water main break above the tunnel. The fire and subsequent events caused disruptions to rail freight movement, local transit systems, and the Internet infrastructure due to damaged fiber optic cables. The study highlights the incident's impact on local, regional, and national transportation systems and provides insights into emergency response, environmental concerns, and inter-agency coordination. It emphasizes lessons learned for improving response protocols, communications, and system resilience during transportation-related disasters.

Implemented a bus bridge to replace disrupted rail services.

Involved private sector partners for chemical assessment and containment.

Provided valuable insights into managing hazardous materials incidents.

Illustrated the need for infrastructure redundancy to minimize disruptions.
Contributed to improved emergency response training and planning.
drawbacks: Delayed initial response due to communication and coordination challenges.

title: Effects of Catastrophic Events on Transportation System Management and Operations: New York City – September 11, 2001
description: This report examines the transportation response to the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks in New York City. It focuses on the impacts on transportation systems, management, and operations due to the destruction of key infrastructure, including the World Trade Center complex, which served as a major intermodal transportation hub. The study provides a detailed chronology of events, highlights the resilience and adaptability of transportation agencies, and identifies lessons learned for emergency preparedness. It evaluates the role of advanced technologies, institutional coordination, and the prioritization of safety over mobility during the crisis. The report emphasizes the need for infrastructure redundancy, robust communication systems, and pre-existing relationships among key personnel to ensure effective disaster response. Key findings offer insights into strengthening transportation system resilience against future catastrophic events.

title: Effects of Catastrophic Events on Transportation System Management and Operations: Northridge Earthquake – January 17, 1994
description: This report analyzes the transportation system's response and recovery efforts following the 1994 Northridge Earthquake in California, which caused severe damage to infrastructure, including freeways, bridges, and transit systems. It evaluates the immediate actions taken by agencies such as Caltrans and the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA), highlights the challenges of managing a disaster in a heavily car-dependent region, and emphasizes the importance of pre-event planning, inter-agency coordination, and rapid decision-making. The earthquake resulted in significant disruptions to mobility in Southern California, where key transportation arteries like I-5, I-10, and SR-14 were severely impacted. Key findings include the importance of system redundancy, the effective use of emergency contracting and incentives, and the necessity for resilient infrastructure. The report offers lessons on disaster preparedness and management that can inform future responses to catastrophic transportation events.

title: Public and Private Benefits in Intelligent Transportation Systems/Commercial Vehicle Operations: Electronic Clearance and Supply Chain Management
description: This report investigates the public and private benefits of Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) with a focus on Commercial Vehicle Operations (CVO). It examines specific ITS applications such as Electronic Clearance (EC) and supply chain management, which improve efficiency, reduce costs, and enhance safety for motor carriers and regulatory agencies. The study evaluates EC systems that allow trucks to bypass inspection stations using transponders, reducing congestion and delays. The report also explores how supply chain management leverages ITS technology for better resource utilization, increased customer satisfaction, and reduced transportation costs. Insights from this research highlight opportunities for collaboration between the private and public sectors to enhance the efficiency of goods movement and regulatory oversight. Recommendations address how lessons learned in private-sector ITS implementation can inform public-sector applications to maximize shared benefits.

title: Effects of Catastrophic Events on Transportation System Management and Operations: Executive Summary of the August 2003 Northeast Blackout
description: This report examines the effects of the August 14, 2003, Northeast Blackout on transportation systems across the affected regions, including New York City, the Great Lakes area, and Cleveland. The blackout resulted from a cascading failure of electrical transmission lines, impacting approximately 50 million people across 3,700 miles. Transportation systems experienced widespread disruptions, including halted rail networks, congested roadways, and failed traffic signals. The study analyzes how transportation agencies responded, the effectiveness of emergency protocols, and the lessons learned. Key themes include the importance of pre-established emergency plans, the role of advanced technology, and the need for redundancy in critical systems. The findings provide actionable insights for improving disaster preparedness and operational resilience in transportation networks.

title: Effects of Catastrophic Events on Transportation System Management and Operations: August 2003 Northeast Blackout in New York City
description: This report delves into the impacts of the August 14, 2003, Northeast Blackout on transportation systems in New York City, emphasizing the response and management strategies employed during the event. The blackout affected 50 million people across 3,700 miles, causing widespread disruptions, including the halting of subway systems, failure of traffic signals, and severe congestion on roadways. The study analyzes decision-making processes, the role of Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS), and the resilience of infrastructure during the crisis. Key findings highlight the importance of emergency preparedness, effective inter-agency coordination, and the application of advanced technologies. Recommendations aim to enhance system redundancy and communication strategies for future emergencies.
notable_practices: Activation of emergency operations centers within minutes of the blackout.
Deployment of traffic agents to manually manage intersections.
Suspension of transit fares to facilitate public mobility during the crisis.
Use of backup power systems for critical infrastructure like bridges and tunnels.
Creation of bus shuttles and ferry services to accommodate stranded commuters.
Implementation of pre-established non-communication response plans.
Reassignment of police to prioritize traffic management and emergency rescue.
Coordination with private and public agencies to secure additional resources.
advantages: Minimized confusion through rapid deployment of emergency operations.
Enabled continuity of some transit services via alternative modes like ferries.
Provided critical lessons for enhancing emergency preparedness.
Facilitated swift evacuation of stranded passengers with well-coordinated efforts.
Highlighted the value of pre-established emergency response plans.
Promoted collaboration between regional agencies and stakeholders.
Encouraged infrastructure upgrades, such as adding backup power to signals.
Demonstrated the need for resilient communication systems during outages.
drawbacks: Initial communication failures delayed coordinated responses.
Severe congestion and chaos on streets and bridges due to system-wide power loss.
Limited backup power for ITS equipment compromised traffic management.
Inconsistent public messaging caused confusion among residents.
Challenges in managing overwhelming demand on ferries and buses.
Economic losses associated with prolonged service disruptions.
Dependence on electrical systems highlighted systemic vulnerabilities.
Insufficient pedestrian management strategies exacerbated congestion.

title: Effects of Catastrophic Events on Transportation System Management and Operations: Comparative Analysis
description: This report provides a comparative analysis of six case studies involving catastrophic events and their impacts on transportation system management and operations. The events include the August 2003 Northeast Blackout, the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in New York City and Washington, D.C., the July 2001 Howard Street Tunnel fire in Baltimore, and the January 1994 Northridge Earthquake in California. The analysis examines the unique challenges presented by each event, the responses by transportation agencies, and the lessons learned. It identifies key themes such as the importance of advanced planning, inter-agency coordination, use of advanced technologies, and building system redundancy. The report aims to provide actionable recommendations for improving the resilience of transportation systems in the face of major disasters.
notable_practices: Development of pre-established emergency response plans and Incident Command Systems (ICS).
Deployment of advanced technologies such as Variable Message Signs (VMS) and CCTV for real-time monitoring.
Implementation of evacuation plans prioritizing safety and security over mobility.
Coordination of multi-agency responses through communication protocols and mutual aid agreements.
Utilization of backup power systems to maintain critical transportation operations during blackouts.
Expansion of ferry services and alternative transit options during service interruptions.
Creation of non-communication plans to enable operations during communication outages.
Conducting post-event reviews to enhance future emergency preparedness and planning.
advantages: Improved readiness through detailed pre-event planning.
Effective management of mobility disruptions during emergencies.
Reduction in public panic through clear and timely communication.
Enhanced inter-agency collaboration led to more coordinated responses.
Use of advanced technologies improved situational awareness.
Increased infrastructure resilience through lessons learned.
Facilitated quicker restoration of transportation services.
Promoted integration of emergency response into transportation planning.
drawbacks: Communication failures delayed initial coordination in several cases.
High costs associated with system restoration and infrastructure repair.
Vulnerabilities in ITS technologies revealed dependency on electrical power.
Difficulty managing public expectations and information during crises.
Strain on agencies due to overlapping jurisdictional responsibilities.
Prolonged recovery times for complex urban infrastructure systems.
Insufficient planning for cascading effects of infrastructure failures.
Overwhelmed emergency responders during simultaneous incidents.

title: Show Me the Money: A Decision-Maker’s Funding Compendium for Transportation Systems Management and Operations
description: This report, published by the Public Technology Institute with funding from the Federal Highway Administration, provides a comprehensive guide to funding options available for transportation systems management and operations (TSM&O). Aimed at state, regional, and local decision-makers, the compendium explores federal, state, and private funding mechanisms. It includes detailed case studies of innovative funding strategies and showcases how creative approaches like toll revenue bonds, public-private partnerships, and federal grants have been used successfully. The document also highlights the operational goals of TSM&O, emphasizing the integration of Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) and the development of multimodal transportation systems to enhance safety, efficiency, and mobility.

Integration of Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) for traffic and transit management.
Public-private partnerships to fund operational costs for pre-clearance systems and ITS infrastructure.
Deployment of CO2 offset credits for traffic signal retiming projects.
Implementation of developer impact fees for transportation system improvements.
Utilization of federal grants such as CMAQ and FTA urbanized area formula grants.
Creation of revenue streams from advertising on transit vehicles and facilities.

title: Integrated Remote Sensing and Visualization (IRSV) System for Transportation Infrastructure Operations and Management: Use of Scanning LiDAR in Structural Evaluation of Bridges
description: This report, part of the IRSV project, investigates the application of terrestrial LiDAR technology for bridge health monitoring and structural evaluation. It details the development of an automated evaluation system, LiBE (LiDAR-based Bridge Evaluation), which uses high-resolution data for detecting defects, measuring clearances, and evaluating displacements in bridge structures. The study focuses on bridges in Mecklenburg County, NC, and demonstrates the potential of LiDAR in reducing costs and improving the efficiency of bridge inspections. The findings suggest that LiDAR technology aligns with state and federal bridge management policies, offering a cost-effective solution to the challenges of aging infrastructure and limited maintenance funding. The report also includes a cost-benefit analysis and discusses how the integration of LiDAR technology could transform traditional bridge inspection practices by enhancing accuracy, reducing inspection time, and standardizing evaluation protocols.
notable_practices: Development of LiBE for automated defect detection and quantification.
Integration of LiDAR data with bridge management systems for improved monitoring.
Application of clearance measurement tools for ensuring compliance with federal standards.
Use of high-resolution data to identify and quantify surface defects.
Cost-benefit analysis to validate the economic viability of LiDAR technology.
Real-world application of LiDAR scanning on bridges with varying conditions.
Cross-validation of LiBE findings with traditional inspection methods.
Standardization of bridge evaluation protocols using quantitative LiDAR data.
advantages: Enhances accuracy and reliability of bridge inspections.
Reduces time and costs associated with traditional inspection methods.
Enables early detection of structural issues, preventing costly repairs.
Supports compliance with federal and state management policies.
Facilitates standardized evaluations across multiple jurisdictions.
Improves safety for inspection personnel by reducing physical access needs.
Promotes data-driven decision-making in infrastructure management.
Scalable technology for application to large bridge inventories.
drawbacks: High initial investment costs for LiDAR equipment and training.
Dependence on software tools for data processing and analysis.
Limited availability of LiDAR expertise among inspection personnel.
Challenges in integrating LiDAR data with existing bridge management systems.
Potential inaccuracies in complex structural geometries.
Weather and environmental conditions may affect data collection quality.
Requirement for continuous technological updates to maintain accuracy.
Resistance from stakeholders accustomed to traditional methods.

title: Integrated Remote Sensing and Visualization (IRSV) System for Transportation Infrastructure Operations and Management: Phase One, Volume One - Summary Report
description: This report discusses the development and application of the Integrated Remote Sensing and Visualization (IRSV) system, designed to enhance transportation infrastructure operations and management with a focus on bridge evaluation. The IRSV incorporates advanced technologies like LiDAR, high-resolution aerial photography, and service-oriented architecture to provide comprehensive insights into infrastructure conditions. By integrating remote sensing data, the system aims to improve decision-making for bridge inspections, streamline damage assessments, and standardize data interpretation processes. The study demonstrates the system’s capability through case studies and pilot tests, showcasing its potential to transform traditional inspection practices. The report emphasizes IRSV’s contribution to enhancing the National Bridge Inspection System (NBIS), supporting state and local agencies in modernizing their infrastructure management strategies, and aligning with national standards for safety and maintenance.

title: Integrated Remote Sensing and Visualization (IRSV) System for Transportation Infrastructure Operations and Management: Phase One, Volume Five - Automated Management Bridge Information System (AMBIS)
description: This volume focuses on the Automated Management Bridge Information System (AMBIS), a critical component of the Integrated Remote Sensing and Visualization (IRSV) system. AMBIS translates raw remote sensing data, including high-resolution aerial photos and ground-based video, into indices that quantify bridge performance. Two major metrics analyzed are deck distress and joint separations, which indicate structural health and potential failure risks. AMBIS serves as a proof-of-concept, demonstrating how remote sensing can identify bridge defects and guide maintenance priorities. The report outlines AMBIS's integration into IRSV, including its data collection, processing, and analysis features. It also emphasizes the system's potential to modernize bridge management by enhancing accuracy, safety, and cost efficiency.

title: Integrated Remote Sensing and Visualization (IRSV) System for Transportation Infrastructure Operations and Management: Phase Two, Volume Two - Applications of LiDAR Technology in Structural Evaluation Under Normal Traffic Operation and Post-Blast Loading
description: This report explores the applications of LiDAR technology in evaluating the structural integrity of transportation infrastructure under normal traffic operations and post-blast loading conditions. It presents methodologies for integrating LiDAR data into transportation system management, offering enhanced accuracy and efficiency in detecting vulnerabilities. The report includes case studies on bridges subjected to normal traffic stress and simulated blast impacts. Findings highlight the potential of LiDAR for both routine monitoring and rapid post-disaster assessment, enabling data-driven decision-making for maintenance and emergency response.

title: Integrated Remote Sensing and Visualization (IRSV) System for Transportation Infrastructure Operations and Management: Phase One, Volume Four - Use of Knowledge Integrated Visual Analytics System in Supporting Bridge Management
description: This report details the development of the Knowledge Integrated Visual Analytics System (KIVAS), an essential component of the IRSV framework aimed at enhancing bridge management. title: Environmental Management System for Transportation Maintenance Operations
description: This report focuses on the development of an Environmental Management System (EMS) for transportation maintenance operations. The system is designed to assist the New Jersey Department of Transportation (NJDOT) in monitoring and reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. By employing a life-cycle analysis framework, the study identifies emissions generated by vehicles, equipment, and materials used in maintenance activities and proposes strategies to minimize environmental impacts. The EMS integrates data from maintenance operations to quantify emissions, assess alternative strategies, and guide decision-making for sustainability. The report includes methodologies for emissions calculation, a conceptual model for the EMS, and recommendations for integrating environmental considerations into operational policies.

title: Evaluating Transportation Systems Management & Operations (TSM&O) Benefits to Alternative Intersection Treatments
description: This report evaluates the benefits of implementing alternative intersection designs under the Transportation Systems Management & Operations (TSM&O) program in Florida. It assesses six major designs: Continuous Flow Intersection (CFI), Diverging Diamond Interchange (DDI), Median U-Turn (MUT), Restricted Crossing U-Turn (RCUT), Quadrant Roadway Intersection (QRI), and Roundabouts. These designs aim to improve intersection efficiency, reduce delays, and enhance safety for all users, including pedestrians and bicyclists. The study includes a comparative analysis of operational performance, safety implications, and benefit-to-cost ratios for each alternative. Findings indicate significant improvements in traffic flow, safety, and cost-effectiveness when these designs are implemented appropriately, aligning with TSM&O goals of optimizing transportation infrastructure performance.
notable_practices: Implementation of Continuous Flow Intersections to reduce left-turn conflicts.
Adoption of Diverging Diamond Interchanges for efficient left-turn operations.
Use of Median U-Turn intersections to eliminate direct left turns.
Integration of Restricted Crossing U-Turn designs to enhance minor road safety.
Application of Quadrant Roadway Intersections to minimize main intersection delays.
Incorporation of roundabouts for reduced conflict points and delay.
Utilization of wayfinding and signage to address driver confusion.
Development of educational programs to familiarize users with alternative designs.
advantages: Significantly reduces intersection delays and increases capacity.
Enhances safety by reducing conflict points for vehicles and pedestrians.
Improves travel time reliability on major and minor roads.
Reduces fuel consumption and emissions due to optimized traffic flow.
Extends the lifespan of existing infrastructure by improving efficiency.
Supports multimodal transportation with pedestrian and bicyclist considerations.
Offers cost-effective alternatives to grade-separated interchanges.
Facilitates scalability for application across various traffic conditions.
drawbacks: High initial costs for design and implementation.
Potential driver confusion with unconventional layouts.
Challenges in retrofitting existing intersections with limited right-of-way.
Increased delays for minor road traffic in some designs.
Additional training required for traffic operators and engineers.
Complexity in managing pedestrian and bicyclist movements in certain designs.
Dependence on public education and signage for successful implementation.
Variable effectiveness based on traffic volume and geographic context.

title: Expanding Transportation Systems Management and Operations (TSM&O) from Planning to Construction Primer
description: This report by the Florida Department of Transportation (FDOT) focuses on enhancing the implementation of Transportation Systems Management and Operations (TSM&O) strategies across all stages of transportation projects, from planning to construction. The report also provides a roadmap for integrating TSM&O strategies with existing infrastructure to optimize performance, improve safety, and reduce costs.

title: Climate Change Adaptation Guide for Transportation Systems Management, Operations, and Maintenance
description: This guide provides practical tools and resources to help transportation agencies integrate climate change considerations into their Transportation Systems Management and Operations (TSM&O) and maintenance programs. It highlights the risks posed by climate change, including extreme weather events, and offers a framework for vulnerability assessment and adaptation. The guide emphasizes collaboration, proactive planning, and the use of data-driven strategies to enhance system resilience. Key elements include defining the scope of adaptation efforts, assessing vulnerabilities, integrating climate considerations into decision-making, and monitoring progress. The guide targets state and local transportation practitioners responsible for ensuring safe, reliable, and efficient surface transportation systems.

title: Improving Transportation Systems Management and Operations (TSM&O): Capability Maturity Model Workshop White Paper
description: This white paper presents findings from a series of Capability Maturity Model (CMM) workshops focused on Transportation Systems Management and Operations (TSM&O). The workshops, conducted at state and regional levels, aimed to identify institutional and process improvements for advancing TSM&O capabilities across six critical dimensions: business processes, systems and technology, performance measurement, culture, organization and staffing, and collaboration. The report highlights the state-of-the-practice, key challenges, and priority actions for enhancing capabilities, with a special focus on the systems and technology dimension. Recommendations include updating ITS architectures, improving procurement processes, and fostering collaboration among stakeholders. The document also provides best practices and a roadmap for integrating TSM&O into state and regional transportation programs.

title: Decision Support Systems for Transportation System Management and Operations (TSM&O)
description: This report introduces an integrated decision support system aimed at enhancing Transportation System Management and Operations (TSM&O). Developed by Florida International University's Lehman Center for Transportation Research, the project integrates two tools: ITS Data Capture and Performance Management (ITSDCAP) and the Integrated Regional Information Sharing and Decision Support System (IRISDS). These systems have been combined into a web-based environment for improved usability, offering real-time and off-line decision-making capabilities. The enhanced system provides functionalities like performance dashboards, benefit-cost analysis for arterial incidents, prediction of arterial breakdowns, and assessment of construction impacts. By incorporating new modules and improving existing ones, the study demonstrates practical applications of decision support for better traffic management and operations planning.

title: Transportation Systems Management and Operations (TSM&O) and Performance-Based Practical Design: Case Study 3
description: This case study highlights the use of Performance-Based Practical Design (PBPD) principles in combination with Transportation Systems Management and Operations (TSM&O) strategies to implement Restricted Crossing U-Turn (RCUT) intersections. These alternative intersections are designed to reduce congestion, improve safety, and optimize corridor performance in a cost-effective manner. The document details the benefits of RCUTs, which eliminate 18 of 32 conflict points at typical four-leg intersections and enable efficient signal timing. title: Exploring Applications for Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) and Unmanned Ground Systems (UGS) in Enhanced Incident Management, Bridge Inspection, and Other Transportation-related Operations

title: Information Flow Analysis on Forced Stop Management of Operation Control System in High-Speed Maglev Transportation
description: This study explores the forced stop management in the Operation Control System (OCS) of high-speed maglev transportation. It examines information flows from external failures, internal system failures, and human interventions to ensure safety during emergencies. The OCS integrates safety-critical systems such as the Vehicle System, Propulsion System, and Guideway Switch System, coordinating these to monitor, dispatch, and provide safety protections. Forced stop management is vital for preventing accidents by stopping the train safely in designated areas upon detecting anomalies like over-speeding or system failures. The research applies information flow analysis, highlighting processes like propulsion shut-off and eddy-current braking. The study's findings guide the simulation, design, and standardization of safety protocols for maglev systems.

title: Advancing Organizational Capabilities for Transportation Systems Management and Operations

title: Raising Awareness of Artificial Intelligence for Transportation Systems Management and Operations
description: This report introduces the fundamentals of Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies and their potential applications in Transportation Systems Management and Operations (TSMO). It covers successful AI implementations, lessons learned, and guidance for future integration. Topics include neural networks, fuzzy logic, machine learning, video analytics, and unmanned aerial systems (UAS). The document emphasizes AI's impact on TSMO activities such as incident detection, traffic signal coordination, and data-driven decision-making. title: Safety Performance Analysis of TSMO: A Practical Approach for Assessing Traffic Signal Coordination Effects on Crash Probability and Severity
description: This report introduces a method for assessing the safety performance effects of Transportation Systems Management and Operations (TSMO) strategies, specifically traffic signal coordination, on crash probability and severity. The Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) developed this framework to address gaps in traditional annual crash analysis methods, which often fail to capture the dynamic interactions between traffic signal timing and crash occurrences. The report focuses on probabilistic models applied at signalized intersections to analyze rear-end and right-angle crashes. Through the use of multinomial and binary logistic regression models, the study explores how vehicle arrival characteristics and traffic signal timing influence crash outcomes. Key insights include strategies for minimizing crashes and improving coordination using data-driven approaches, supported by advanced signal timing plans and high-resolution traffic data.

title: Operation Management of Multiregion Battery Swapping–Charging Networks for Electrified Public Transportation Systems
description: This paper presents a comprehensive model for managing multiregion battery swapping and charging networks (MBSCN) to support the efficient operation of electrified public transportation systems. The research introduces a closed-loop supply chain network-based model and a multilayer time–space network (TSN) technique for optimizing battery logistics. The model addresses uncertainties in electric vehicle (EV) user behavior using a distributionally robust chance-constrained service model, which requires no assumptions on probability distributions. By integrating interregional battery logistics and leveraging locational energy pricing, the MBSCN model enhances operational efficiency and flexibility, ensuring high-quality service provision. The optimization framework is validated through case studies, demonstrating significant cost reductions, improved system reliability, and potential solutions for congestion in distribution systems.

title: Promoting the Transportation Systems Management & Operations Program in Kansas
description: This report evaluates the current level of Transportation Systems Management and Operations (TSMO) implementation within the Kansas Department of Transportation (KDOT). The research outlines a cooperative control framework integrating centralized and decentralized decision-making, tailored to varying levels of automation and cooperation as defined by SAE J3216™. title: Supporting Transportation System Management and Operations Using Internet of Things Technology
description: This report investigates the potential of Low Power Wide-Area Network (LPWAN) technology in supporting Transportation Systems Management and Operations (TSMO). Conducted under the sponsorship of the Virginia Department of Transportation (VDOT), it evaluates the feasibility and performance of LPWAN, particularly LoRa, in various applications like parking monitoring, remote flood sensing, and data transmission for Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS). The study includes a comprehensive literature review, an online survey targeting transportation professionals, and lab tests on university and rural settings. Lab results demonstrate that factors like device height, distance, and hardware affect performance. The research concludes with a field test plan to guide future studies and address technical challenges like transmission rates, deployment requirements, and scalability.

title: Investigating the Role of Dimension Reduction in Counteracting Machine Learning Performance Bias in TSMO Strategies
description: This study evaluates how machine learning models can mitigate performance bias in Transportation Systems Management and Operations (TSMO) strategies. Performance bias occurs when machine learning models yield inconsistent results across different incident scenarios. The paper investigates dimension-reduction techniques, such as feature selection and Principal Component Analysis (PCA), to reduce this bias. Seven machine learning models (RF, BRNN, SVR, KNN, XGB, GP, and NNET) are tested using incident clearance time data from Missouri interstates. PCA significantly reduces performance bias and improves global error metrics, particularly for scenarios involving severe incidents. The findings suggest that integrating PCA into model development enhances reliability and reduces error variability, making it a valuable tool for improving machine learning applications in TSMO.
